Course Title:　　English in Practice

Course Description:　　This course is designed (1) to strengthen students' previously required knowledge in English with basic grammatical ideas and sentence patterns reviewed through reading materials appropriate to their levels; (2) to develop reading skill by giving explanation of difficult words, phrases, and syntax, as well as analysis of basic writing skill; (3) to familiarize students with useful expressions in conversation and build up their confidence in cross-cultural communication; (4) to reinforce the competence and performance of listening, speaking, reading and writing by practice.

課程重點：(1)藉由適合其程度的教材加強學生必備的基礎文法觀念和句型結構；(2)使學生確切把握閱讀要領以及充分瞭解寫作的各種技巧，重心在生字、片語、句法的解釋和基本寫作技巧的分析；(3)熟悉英語人士日常生活情境及與學生將來就業環境相關之會話及適當之應對方式；(4)透過練習加強聽、說、讀、寫的知能及表達。


Content Outline:  The course is organized around listening, note-taking, and discussion of content taught in American history and culture courses in high schools, colleges, and universities in the United States.  However, the listening, note-taking, and discussion tasks help students develop the skills they need for study in any academic discipline.  Students are also given opportunities to practice giving individual/paired and group presentations over textbook content and researched information.  Listening activities will center on the listening of academic lectures and less formal interviews.  Dialogue journals will be used as the method of providing students with the opportunity to improve English writing.  

Course Objectives:  By the end of the course students will have:
‧　　Shown knowledge of how to take notes on academic lectures to answer questions.  
‧　　Shown written English improvement.
‧　　Successfully given an individual/paired short presentation.
‧　　Successfully done research and given short group presentations.
‧　　Shown the ability to participate in class discussions.

Instructional Activities:  This course is first and foremost a discussion course.  Students must actively participate in class through discussion with the teacher and classmates.  Students will follow their textbook as it guides them in the discussion of American history and culture.  When expected, students are expected to present their ideas during presentations.  Dialogue journals will be used to allow students the opportunity to critically discuss what has been discussed during class.  

Dialogue journals are written conversations between student and teacher.  Topics will be selected by both the student and by the teacher.  Students will write an entry and the teacher responds.  The student then reads what the teacher has written and responds.  The student determines how long or short the entry will be.  This will decide how long or short the reply from the teacher will be.  This journal will provide a student with the opportunity to practice writing at one’s own level, receive individualized attention and regular positive feedback, write and read for authentic purpose –to communicate (fluency) but have the teacher model correct usage (accuracy), have the opportunity for reflection and personal response, and have a record of written language development.  This type of writing also allows the teacher to become more acquainted with individual students, provide individualized instruction, and receive frequent assessment of student progress.
